categories.title: AI Agent Council Prototype and Tech Insights

content.text: A first prototype of an AI agent council is nearing completion, designed to simulate movie-like scenes where agents represent different viewpoints on decisions or proposals. This is part of automation work for Clank Tank that could be applied to speed up production for other shows as well.

The 'docs as code' philosophy is gaining importance in the agentic era, as AI can read documentation much faster than humans, enabling rapid onboarding and scaling of AI teams. AI with knowledge of documentation can filter information into more accessible language for humans, and LLMs can help create prompts for visual illustrations of complex topics.
Security tip: Avoid using SMS for two-factor authentication when possible, and consider services like Google Voice or Hushed when sharing phone numbers.
Clank Tank Episode 1 has been released, with Episode 2 coming soon.

Motivational insights: Don't wait for permission or fear failure; treat setbacks as feedback, question defaults, and seek truth rather than comfort. Be persistent, debug your thinking, stay with problems longer, and be creative.

# ElizaOS Technical Issues and Solutions

The Discord chat focused on troubleshooting ElizaOS plugin installations, local AI configuration, and client issues. Users encountered problems with plugin visibility after installation via CLI and Bun. The recommended solution was to use git clone of the ElizaOS repo, switch to the v2-develop branch, and run bun install, bun run build, and bun start.

Multiple users reported the Twitter client failing to reply to users despite checking interactions. A GitHub issue (#4115) was referenced, but no definitive fix was found, though switching to different install methods helped in some cases.

Local AI setup issues were common, with users struggling with the system defaulting to LLaMA models despite setting OpenAI or Anthropic API keys. The solution involved setting specific environment variables in the .env file to bypass LLaMA downloads and use cloud-based models instead.

Other issues included API rate limit crashes with Anthropic, VRAM problems on 4070 Super GPUs, and dependency resolution errors during installation. Most were resolved through proper configuration of the .env file or switching to the v2-develop branch.

# Community Documentation and Onboarding Improvements

The Discord chat focused on improving ElizaOS's community documentation and onboarding processes. Key discussions included:

- Creating dual-layered documentation (technical and non-technical) to serve different contributor types
- Implementing a flowchart-based FAQ system with metadata-tagged plugins/articles
- Balancing organized structure with open-source flexibility
- Integrating community documentation with technical documentation
- Developing a tokenomic model involving a two-pool system (SOL/Agent Token and ai16z buybacks)
- Measuring success through Discord engagement, developer activity, and external mentions
- Using platforms like eliza.how and elizaos.ai with integrated chatbots for real-time Q&A

Contributors identified developers, AI researchers, community managers, and content creators as primary target audiences. There was strong consensus that documentation should be accessible while providing clear paths to technical depth when needed.

# AI-Generated Content Improvements

Discussions focused on improving AI-generated summaries, data aggregation, and video production:

1. **AI-News Project**: The m3-org/ai-news project aims to enhance accessibility and accuracy of AI-generated summaries for Eliza and Hyperfy. Proposed improvements include using LLMs to analyze sample files, generate prompt ideas, identify data gaps, and create dashboard prototypes for better visualization. A script-based approach for generating weekly newsletters was shared, allowing the entire DAO history to be summarized within a single context window.

2. **Clanktank Video Production**: A major update to the Clanktank project enables going from pitch to video in 30 seconds using placeholder assets. Improvements include baking sets, animating camera paths, integrating clip transitions, and automating video recording/editing scripts. The biggest bottleneck was avatar generation, which recent 3D AI breakthroughs are helping to solve. GPT-4o and Photoshop AI are being used for thumbnail and character image generation, though rate limiting issues were reported even on pro plans.

# Trading Activity on Pump.fun Platform

The Discord chat focused on real-time trading activity and sentiment analysis on the Pump.fun platform, primarily discussing Solana-based meme and microcap tokens. Users tracked tokens like AGiXT (which grew from 7.9M to 9.7M market cap), Torpedo Bat, Jet A, BOOBA TEE, and others.

Technical aspects included:
- Use of bot commands (.dp, .cc, .c, .x) to fetch token data through a Discord bot (likely Rick)
- Discussion of bonding mechanisms for tokens like Supertits and Torpedo Bat
- Analysis of token fundamentals and developer credibility
- Debate over the upcoming Auto Fun launchpad and its potential to redefine the AI token meta
- Scam detection techniques and skepticism about projects like Meddex's claim of a $26M buyback

The chat was primarily speculative in nature, with users sharing contract addresses, discussing token performance, and employing swing trading strategies to accumulate positions during volatility.

categories.title: Recent Pull Requests in elizaOS/eliza Repository

content.text: Several bug fixes have been implemented in recent pull requests. The Groq plugin was updated to handle retries more gracefully (PR #4118). Issues with the Telegram plugin were addressed (PR #4106). The Docker image size was reduced (PR #4120), and a typo in Thai text for file path documentation was corrected (PR #4116).

A significant architectural change was made by separating Ollama functionality. Ollama code was removed from LocalAI (PR #4122) and a separate Ollama plugin was created (PR #4121). This modularization likely improves maintainability and separation of concerns.

Testing improvements were made with updates to resolve failing CLI test cases (PR #4100) and the addition of tests for the project-starter directory (PR #4089). Additionally, dependencies were updated through an automated PR that bumped npm and yarn packages across one directory with two updates (PR #4064).

## Installation Problems

Users are experiencing multiple issues when trying to install and use the ElizaOS CLI:

1. The standard installation command `npm install -g @elizaos/cli@latest` fails with dependency errors, specifically related to `@elizaos/plugin-sql@^0.25.6` which cannot be found in the npm registry.

2. The quickstart guide on eliza.how contains outdated or inaccurate instructions. A workaround identified by users is to use the beta tag: `npm install -g @elizaos/cli@beta`.

3. After installation, users encounter errors when running commands like `npx elizaos create` followed by `npx elizaos start`, with errors indicating "agents already exists".

## Twitter Plugin Issues

The Twitter plugin has several bugs:

1. Duplicate memory creation: When someone mentions the bot on Twitter, the system tries to create a memory record twice with the same ID, resulting in database constraint violations.

2. Configuration problems: The Twitter post interval configuration is not being properly read, resulting in null values in the logs (`Post Interval: null-null minutes`).

3. Difficulty controlling interactions: Users cannot effectively block specific Twitter accounts from interacting with their agent, even after removing them from configuration files and blocking them on Twitter.

## Suggested Improvements

There are several proposed improvements for the CLI tool instructions:

1. Include a link to eliza.how for documentation
2. Mention OpenRouter free models as an option
3. Update command instructions to use the beta tag while still in beta: `npx @elizaos/cli@beta start` or `elizaos start` if CLI is installed

Here's a snapshot of current cryptocurrency prices:

- Bitcoin (WBTC): $82,251.77 - $82,581.85
- Ethereum (WETH): $1,806.79
- Solana (SOL): $124.63
- ai16z: $0.16 - $0.16

Note: There appears to be a slight fluctuation in the WBTC price between the two data points, with a difference of about $330. Similarly, ai16z shows a small price variation between the two reported values.

categories.title: Recent Pull Requests in elizaOS/eliza Repository

content.text:
Several pull requests have been submitted to the elizaOS/eliza repository addressing various improvements and fixes:

- Documentation updates (PR #4114 by madjin)
- A fix for the Groq plugin to handle retries more gracefully (PR #4118 by wtfsayo)
- Correction of a typo in Thai text for file path (PR #4116 by 0xbryer)
- Email-related changes (PR #4123 by Cooops)
- Addition of a separate Ollama plugin (PR #4121 by wtfsayo)
- Fix for room and entity synchronization in Telegram (PR #4124 by 0xbbjoker)

These changes collectively improve documentation, fix bugs, and add new functionality to the eliza project.

Recent development efforts focused on package improvements across multiple areas. These included enhancements to the Twitter plugin for post generation and running a linter. The Groq plugin was also improved to handle retries more gracefully. New features were added, such as a monorepo command to the CLI. A total of 3 bug fixes were implemented across the codebase. This work involved 5 contributors who merged 5 PRs in total. The major work primarily consisted of various improvements to the existing codebase.
sources: text: Development focused on package improvements (twitter plugin post generation + ran linter), new features (add monorepo command to cli), 2 bug fixes. with 5 contributors merging 4 PRs. Major work included various improvements.

content.text: The elizaos/eliza repository showed increased activity over a two-day period. From March 30-31, 2025, there were 3 new PRs with 2 merged, 3 new issues, and 9 active contributors. Activity increased the following day (March 31-April 1, 2025) with 5 new PRs, 7 merged PRs, 1 new issue, and 12 active contributors. Overall, this represents growth in both contributions and contributor count.

The provided sources mention 'Top contributors for elizaOS/eliza' but do not provide any specific details about who these contributors are or their contributions to the project. Without additional information, it's not possible to generate a detailed summary about the individual contributors, their roles, or the nature of their contributions to the elizaOS/eliza project.
